Question: Why was this treatise composed?
Answer: In order to show that the great merit of the appearance of buddhas in the world.
As the PrajÃ±aptiÅ›Ästra says:
On the edge of JambudvÄ«pa, surrounding the ocean,
there is a road for the wheel-turning king, one yojana wide.
If the wheel-turning kings do not appear in the world, it is covered by water and no one can travel on it.
If they appear in the world, the seawater recedes by one yojana,
and this road appears, level, decorated, and pure, with golden sand on the bottom.
It is naturally sprinkled and moistened with sandalwood-scented water.
Whenever the wheel-turning king wishes to tour this continent,
he travels this road with his fourfold army as his escort.
In this way, when the buddhas have not yet appeared in the world,
there is no one who can rely on the fundamental stages to eliminate afflictions.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
When the great Dharma-wheel-turning king of the ten powers appears in the world,
The fundamental ground manifests equality and purity.
It spreads the sand of the factors of enlightenment and sprinkles the water of precepts and concentration.
The Buddha, together with countless retinues of nayutas,
Rely on it to enter the palace of fearlessness and nirvana.
Question: How does this show that when the Buddha appears in the world, he has great merit?
Answer: If the Buddha did not appear in the world, this question would not even exist, let alone having an answer.
As the Buddha was once dwelling in the Kalandaka Bamboo Grove in the city of ÅšrÄvastÄ«,
There was a bhiká¹£u named AÅ›vajit.
He was an arhat.
Alone in a quiet room, he had this thought:
Where are the four great elements permanently extinguished?
In order to know this, he entered into excellent meditative absorption.
With his mind in concentration, he disappeared from the Kalandaka Bamboo Grove
And suddenly appeared in the heaven of the Four Heavenly Kings.
Rising from concentration, he asked the heavenly beings:
Where are the four great elements permanently extinguished?
The heavenly beings replied:
We do not know where these four great elements are eternally extinguished.
However, the four heavenly kings whom we serve,
their wisdom and virtue are all exceptionally excellent.
Perhaps they can understand this, we can go ask them.
The Venerable one then went to the Four Heavenly Kings,
and asked as above, but they all said they did not know.ğŸ”½They then jointly looked up to the Thirty-three Heaven multitude.
The Thirty-three Heaven multitude also looked up to Åšakra.ğŸ”½Åšakra looked up to the YÄma Heaven multitude.
The YÄma Heaven multitude looked up to the YÄma prince.ğŸ”½The YÄma prince looked up to the Tuá¹£ita Heaven multitude.
The Tuá¹£ita Heaven multitude looked up to the Saá¹ƒtuá¹£ita prince.
The Saá¹ƒtuá¹£ita prince

looked up to the NirmÄá¹‡arati Heaven multitude.ğŸ”½The NirmÄá¹‡arati Heaven multitude looked up to the NirmÄá¹‡arati prince.ğŸ”½The NirmÄá¹‡arati prince looked up to the ParanirmitavaÅ›avartin Heaven multitude.
The ParanirmitavaÅ›avartin Heaven multitude looked up to the VaÅ›avartin prince.
The celestial son of Wonderful Freedom pushed the Brahma Heaven multitude.
Thus, the Venerable One asked the desire heavens in this way.
He was unable to know the place where the great elements ceased.
He wanted to go to the Brahma world and enter into concentration.
Again, with a concentrated mind, he disappeared from the palace.
He emerged in the Brahma Heaven multitude.
He arose from concentration and asked as above.
The Brahma multitude all said:
We do not know that there is a Great Brahma King.
He is the creator and transformer of Brahma.
He is the father of all, born with great freedom.
He possesses great authority and virtue, unmatched by anyone.
There is no one who does not see, understand, or recognize him.
He is definitely able to know. You should go and ask him.
The Venerable One then asked where the Great Brahma was.
The Brahma multitude replied:
We also do not know the definite location of the Great Brahma King.
If you want to see him, search for him everywhere.
Then there will be a light that appears in the midst of that.
The Venerable AÅ›vajit then gave rise to a sincere mind.
May the great Brahma king manifest himself to this assembly.
At that time, the great Brahma immediately emitted light.
He then transformed his body into the form of a youth.
His head had five peaks and his appearance was dignified.
He appeared in the Brahma assembly following the light.
The Venerable one went forward and asked,
Great sage, where are the four great elements permanently extinguished?
The Brahma king, not understanding, spoke in a confused manner.
Bhiká¹£us should know that I am the great Brahma,
the sovereign, the creator,
the transformer,
the giver of life, the nourisher, the father of all.
This is a verbal action born from flattery and deception.
The Venerable one said,
I do not ask you about being Brahma or not being Brahma, etc.
I only ask where the great elements are permanently extinguished.
At that time, the great Brahma knew that this bhiká¹£u's words were not confused and could respond immediately.
He took the bhiká¹£u's two hands and led him out of the assembly.
This is a bodily action born from flattery and deception.
After coming out of the assembly, he apologized to the Venerable one, saying,
I truly do not know where the great elements cease.
However, all the Brahma assemblies think that I am the sovereign creator, who knows and sees everything.
If I were to say in the assembly that I do not know,
then the Brahma assemblies would look down on me with contempt.
The Venerable One himself lost and recently abandoned the TathÄgata.
Far away, he troubled the Buddha with his questions and gained nothing.
Now he should quickly return to the Buddha and ask him.
As the Buddha says, he should accept and uphold it.
When AÅ›vajit heard the Brahma King praising the Buddha,
he joyfully took leave and retired, and again entered samÄdhi.
With a mind in samÄdhi, he disappeared from the Brahma world
and suddenly reappeared in the Jeta Grove.
Emerging from samÄdhi, he adjusted his robes
and went before the World-Honored One, respectfully made prostrations,
and asked where the four great elements are eternally extinguished.
At that time, the World-Honored One told him the parable of the bird with invisible limits, saying:
You are also like this. Up to the Brahma Palace, you asked everywhere,
but could not find the limits and returned here.
Just like that bird cannot reach its limit.
However, the question you asked does not accord with the proper manner of questioning.
Answering according to this also goes against the principle of answering.
If you wish to ask,
you should ask like this:
The four great elements and short, long, fine, coarse, pure, and impure -
where is it forever abandoned, with name-and-form extinguished without remainder?
This question accords with the proper manner of questioning, and you should answer like this:
Consciousness does not see the boundless, all-pervading, vast nature.
There is no other vastness that can surpass this.
The four great elements and short, long, fine, coarse, pure, and impure -
where is it forever abandoned, with name-and-form extinguished without remainder?
Some say:
Here the Buddha speaks of the noble path.
The World-Honored One speaks of the sound of consciousness in this.
Some say:
Here the Buddha speaks of nirvana.
Because he speaks of the boundless consciousness not being seen.
If there is no Buddha appearing in the world to speak the true Dharma, then even Brahma would be mostly deluded.
If the Buddha appears in the world and expounds the true Dharma, then even an eight-year-old novice monk can understand it.
Suppose someone comes and asks, Do you know, elder?
Where do the four great elements cease forever?
If they recite and uphold the aggregate of the great elements,
they would say that they cease based on the four meditations or based on the preliminary stage of the first meditation.
If the world has no Buddha, then these [novice monks] would have no [such knowledge].
Therefore, the Buddha's appearance in the world has great merit.
Based on which meditation do the four great elements and the form derived from them cease?
The answer is: They cease based on the four meditations or based on the preliminary stage of the first meditation.
It is also called the path, or the track,
or the antidote,
or the mental attention.

and the other was named GhosilÄrÄma.
The Venerable Tivira said:
Here, it only speaks of permanent elimination without remainder.

That sÅ«tra only speaks of the fundamental stages.

The others are not so.

The question is asked: This treatise is established based on the SÅ«tra on the Seven Abodes.
That sÅ«tra only speaks of the fundamental stages.

The answer is: For this reason, it is said that Abhidharma is the mirror, lamp, flame, and light of the sÅ«tras.
What has not been proclaimed in the sÅ«tras is proclaimed here.
What has not been manifested is manifested here.
The sÅ«tras speak of what remains.
Here, there is nothing remaining.
The sÅ«tras speak with a different intention.
Here, there is no different intention.
In the Abhidharma, the words are mostly in accordance with the ultimate principle.
For this reason, the two explanations of the sÅ«tras and treatises are well understood.
The great elements and derivative form cease based on the four concentrations means:

It should not be said that it is based on the not yet attained.

This text mentions the fundamental stage twice.
The four concentrations are called the four supported concentrations.
The not yet attained refers to all the supports.
It manifests all the not yet attained.
It does not directly say that the not yet attained is the support.
It is like saying entering the city or not yet entering the city.
Although the word city is mentioned twice, there is no separate matter of the city.

Other masters say:
Here the word support generally refers to all concentrations.
It is not only the fundamental stage.
All are able to serve as the support for the path.
However, the seven bases are spoken of in terms of their superiority, and the great elements and derivative form are bound to five stages.
Namely, the desire realm and the four meditations.

Abiding in the fruit of no-more-training.
Or those who do not abide anywhere.
This refers to a person who has already severed and completely known the faculty of pleasure.
But has still not abided in the fruit.
That is, ordinary beings who have already become free from the defilements of the third meditative absorption.
Or those who were previously free from those defilements.
Enter into the correct certainty of birthlessness.
Abiding in the path of seeing for fifteen moments.
If they are gradual,
Free from the defilements of the third meditative absorption.
In the final path of liberation, free from the defilements of the fourth meditative absorption.
The various paths of added effort, nine uninterrupted paths, nine paths of liberation.
Up to being free from the defilements of the sphere of nothingness.
One should know it is also like this.
Free from the defilements of the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception.
The various paths of added effort, nine uninterrupted paths, eight paths of liberation.
Abiding in these various states, the person.
The faculty of pleasure has already been severed and completely known.
Regarding the four fruits of the Å›ramaá¹‡a,
they still have not attained stability.
Question: Having previously become free from the defilements of the third meditative absorption,
when entering the path of the cognition of the principles of the path that leads to the definitive emergence from the three realms,
at that time the faculty of pleasure has already been eliminated and completely understood.
This person abides in the fruit of non-returning.
Why is this not mentioned here?
Answer: That which should be mentioned but is not mentioned should be understood as having a remainder of meaning.
Some say:
Here, based on the gradual explanation, it is explained in detail as before.
The faculty of joy has already been eliminated and completely understood.
It should be said that one abides in which fruit?
Answer: The fruit of arhatship.
Or, one does not abide anywhere.
One who abides in the fruit of arhatship,
refers to that person whose faculty of joy has already been eliminated and completely understood.
Abiding in the fruit of the state beyond training.
Not abiding anywhere refers to that person
whose faculty of joy has already been eliminated and completely understood.
Still, one has not yet attained the fruit.
That is to say, ordinary beings who have already become free from the defilements of the second meditative absorption,
or who have previously become free from those defilements,
Entering the correct certainty of birthlessness.
Abiding in the path of seeing for fifteen moments.
If gradually,
Separating from the defilements of the second concentration.
The final path of liberation.
Separating from the defilements of the third concentration.
All the paths of preparation, nine uninterrupted paths, and nine paths of liberation.
Up to separating from the defilements of the sphere of nothingness.
One should know it is also like this.
Separating from the defilements of the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception.
All the paths of preparation, nine uninterrupted paths, and eight paths of liberation.
Abiding in these states, the person has already severed and completely known the faculty of joy.
But they have still not attained the four fruits of the Å›ramaá¹‡a.
Question: Having previously separated from the defilements of the second concentration,
Entering the path of correct certainty of birthlessness, at the time of the knowledge of the path and its categories,
At that time, the faculty of joy has already been severed and completely known.
This person abides in the fruit of non-returning.
Why is this not mentioned here?
Answer: That which should be said but is not said should be known to have a remainder of meaning.
Some say:
Here, it is explained in sequence.
As extensively explained before, the faculty of suffering and the faculty of grief are the food of morsels.
Having already been eliminated and already been fully understood,
it should be said that one abides in which fruit?
The answer is: the fruit of non-returning.
Or the fruit of arhatship.
Or abiding in none.
Abiding in the fruit of non-returning refers to
when that person has already eliminated and fully understood the three faculties of suffering, etc.
Abiding in the third fruit of learning.
Abiding in the fruit of arhatship refers to
when that person has already eliminated and fully understood the three faculties of suffering, etc.
Abiding in the fruit of no-more-learning.
Abiding in none refers to
when that person has already eliminated and fully understood the three faculties of suffering, etc.
Still not abiding in the fruit.
That is, ordinary beings who have already separated from the defilements of the desire realm,
or who have previously separated from those defilements,
enter into the correct certainty of separation from birth.
Abiding in the path of seeing for fifteen moments.
Abiding in these various states, the person
has already eliminated and fully understood the three faculties of suffering, etc.
but they have not yet attained the four fruits of the Å›ramaá¹‡a.
Here, the stages of gradual progress are not called without abiding.
When the final uninterrupted path arises, free from the defilements of the desire realm,
at that time, the three faculties of suffering and so forth are completely eliminated.
At the time of the final path of liberation,
this person must abide in the fruit of non-returning.
The faculties of rejection, contact, conceptualization, and consciousness have already been eliminated and completely known.
It should be said that they abide in which fruit?
The answer is: the fruit of arhatship.
Here it is not said.
Or without abiding.
Why is it so?
Free from the defilements of the sphere of neither-perception-nor-non-perception,
when the final uninterrupted path arises, at that time, the three nutriments of rejection are completely eliminated.
At the time of the final path of liberation,
this person must abide in the fruit of arhatship.
Therefore, other masters give a separate interpretation of this.
That is to say, this question asks about the four great elements, etc., which have already been eliminated and completely known.
It should be said that they are included in which fruit?
Therefore, it is not said that the four great elements, etc. have already been completely eliminated and known.
Abiding in the fruit of non-returning, having previously abandoned the defilements of the form realm,
later entering the correct state of separation from birth, at the time of the knowledge of the lineage of the path, although one attains the fruit of non-returning,
the separation from those [defilements] is not included in the fruit of non-returning.
Because the fruit of non-returning only includes the elimination of what is eliminated by seeing,
and what is eliminated by cultivation in the desire realm.
In order to eliminate the fruit.
The first explanation is said to be good.
Why is it so?
Here, it only asks about the person, the four great elements, etc. that have already been completely eliminated and known,
and attaining which fruit to abide in, but does not ask about what is included in the fruit.
The sutra says that there are four kinds of food.
The first is coarse food.
The second is contact as food.
The third is intention as food.
The fourth is consciousness as food.
What is coarse food?
It is said to be the condition of being divided into coarse and fine parts,
which nourishes the faculties
and benefits the great elements.ğŸ”½What is contact, intention, and consciousness as food?
It is said that contaminated contact, intention, and consciousness are the conditions.
Nourishing the faculties.
Increasing the great elements.
Among them, nourishing the faculties
Shows the nourishing of all dharmas.
Increasing the great elements
Shows the karmic retribution of all dharmas.
Question: The faculties can also be increased because they have karmic retribution.
The great elements can also be nourished because they have nourishment.
Why is it only said here?
Answer: The faculties and the great elements should both be spoken of in two ways.
But it is not said, one should know that this meaning is incomplete.
Furthermore, it is in order to use various texts and various explanations
To adorn the meaning and make it easy to understand.
Furthermore, it is in order to show two gates, two steps, two summaries, two lights, two torches, two shadows, and two rays,
Mutually illuminating each other as explained by the faculties.
Nourishing the great elements should also be so.
As explained by the great elements, the faculties should also be so.
Because the two gates and so forth mutually illuminate each other.
Then the explained principle is comprehensive and the essential meaning of the text is evident.
Question: As explained, nourishing and increasing,
is it nourishing and increasing with respect to dharmas that are nourished and increased,
or is it nourishing and increasing with respect to dharmas that are not nourished and increased?
If it is nourishing and increasing with respect to dharmas that are nourished and increased,
then what is nourished and increased with respect to those dharmas that are nourished and increased?
If it is nourishing and increasing with respect to dharmas that are not nourished and increased,
how is it nourishing and increasing with respect to dharmas that are not nourished and increased?
Answer: It is neither nourishing and increasing with respect to dharmas that are nourished and increased,
nor is it nourishing and increasing with respect to dharmas that are not nourished and increased.
Rather, dharmas that are nourished and increased and dharmas that are not nourished and increased abide in the future.
If they encounter conditions that nourish and increase,
then dharmas that are not nourished and increased cease,
and dharmas that are nourished and increased arise.
If they encounter conditions that do not nourish and increase, then dharmas that are nourished and increased cease,
and dharmas that are not nourished and increased arise.
Although there is no transformation, the meaning is established in both cases.
Question: Can there be contaminated contact, volition, and consciousness that serve as conditions,ğŸ”½nourishing the faculties,
and increasing the primary elements,
but not be food?
Answer: There can be.
It refers to contact, intention, and consciousness of different realms that can nourish and benefit the faculties and primary elements.
Is there any contact, intention, and consciousness of the same realm that serve as conditionsğŸ”½to nourish the faculties
and benefit the primary elements,
but are not nutriments?
The answer is: there is.
It refers to contact, intention, and consciousness of different stages that can nourish and benefit the faculties and primary elements.
Is there any contact, intention, and consciousness of the same stage that serve as conditionsğŸ”½to nourish the faculties
and benefit the primary elements,
but are not nutriments?
The answer is: there is.
It refers to uncontaminated contact, intention, and consciousness.
They can nourish and benefit the faculties and primary elements.
Why are uncontaminated [dharmas] not established as nutriments?
The answer is: because uncontaminated dharmas do not have the characteristics of nutriments.
Moreover, dharmas that manifest and benefit existence,ğŸ”½that embrace existence,
that uphold existence,
can be said to be nutriments.
Uncontaminated dharmas
harm, oppose, and destroy existence, therefore they are not called nutriments.
Moreover, dharmas that manifest continuously perpetuate existence.
Continuous aging and death can cause the wheel of birth and death to turn endlessly.
They can be said to be food.
Pure dharmas cut off and stop all existence.
They cut off and stop aging and death.
They can cause birth and death to no longer revolve, so they are not said to be food.
Moreover, dharmas that manifest accord with suffering and its accumulation.
They accord with aging and death.
They can cause the existence of birth and death.
The turning of the world does not cease, so they can be said to be food.
Pure dharmas accord with the cessation of suffering and its accumulation.
They accord with the cessation of aging and death. They can cause the existence of birth and death and the world to no longer turn, so they are not said to be food.
Moreover, dharmas that manifest are the affairs of the view of the self.
They are the affairs of the inversions.
They are the affairs of craving and love.
They are the affairs of the latent tendencies.
They are the established bases of greed, anger, and delusion.
They have defilements, poisons,
impurities, and turbidity.
They have thorns and enemies.
All that is included
falls into the truths of suffering and its accumulation.
It can be said to be food.
The pure dharmas are not the objects of the view of self,
are not the objects of the perversions,
are not the objects of craving,
are not the objects of the latent afflictions,
are not the basis for the establishment of greed, hatred, and delusion,ğŸ”½are without defilements, without poison,
without impurity, without turbidity,
without thorns, without enemies,
are not included in anything,
and do not fall into the truths of suffering and accumulation, therefore they are not said to be food.
Moreover, the pure dharmas cannot ultimately nourish existence.
Although they temporarily nourish, they are not ultimate, therefore they are not said to be food.
The Venerable Subhagupta also says:
The pure dharmas do not nourish existence.
Although they temporarily nourish, they are not ultimate.
Because they ultimately go against existence, they are not said to be food.
That which is said to be food can ultimately nourish.
Question: What is the essence of food?
Answer: It is the sixteen substances.
Among them, thirteen substances are the essence of material food.
They are the eleven contacts, and the faculties of smell and taste.
The three of contact, intention, and consciousness are the substance of the other two foods.
As for the inclusion of aggregates, realms, and bases,
it is included in a small part of eleven realms, five bases, and three aggregates.
As for the eleven realms,
they are the seven mind realms,
as well as the realms of smell, taste, touch, and dharmas.
As for the five bases,
they are the bases of smell, taste, touch,
the mind base,
and the dharma base.
As for the three aggregates,
they are the form aggregate, the formation aggregate, and the consciousness aggregate.
This is the intrinsic nature of the four foods.
The nature, characteristics, and self-substantiality.
The intrinsic nature has already been explained.
The reason will now be explained.
Why are they called foods?
What is the meaning of food?
The answer is: the meaning of food is the meaning of drawing existence,ğŸ”½the meaning of continuing existence,
the meaning of maintaining existence,
the meaning of producing existence,ğŸ”½the meaning of nourishing existence,
the meaning of increasing existence,
this is the meaning of food.
Because these four are able to draw existence,
up to being able to increase it, they are called food.
Question: If drawing existence,ğŸ”½up to increasing existence is the meaning of food,
then
All defiled dharmas should be called nutriments.
Why are only four mentioned?
Venerable PÄrÅ›va said:
Only the World-Honored Buddha has thoroughly realized the nature and characteristics of all dharmas.
He also knows their power and function, which others cannot know.
If a dharma has the characteristics and function of nutriment, it can be established as nutriment.
Then it is established.
If not, it is not established.
Venerable Vasumitra said:
This is the remainder of the World-Honored One's teachings.
It is a brief teaching, an indirect teaching, and a teaching with a specific purpose.
Because the Buddha teaches the Dharma according to the needs of those to be taught.
Venerable SubhÅ«ti said:
The Buddha knows that these four strongly pull, continue, maintain, give rise to, nourish, increase, and form the characteristics and functions of existence.
They are established as nutriments because they are powerful, proximate, and so forth.
Other dharmas are not like this, so they are not called nutriments.
Other masters say:
These four dharmas are able to greatly nourish the realms, destinies, birth, old age, and death of the world.
They cause them to revolve, so they are established as nutriments.
The other three do not.
Some say:
Food has two characteristics.ğŸ”½One is to attract future existence and bring it to the present.
The other is to sustain present existence and cause it to continue.
Other masters say:
Food is of three kinds.
One is karmic food.
Two is food for birth.
Three is food for nourishment.
Karmic food refers to intention.
Food for birth refers to consciousness.
Food for nourishment
Refers to morsels and contact.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
